metadata.case_name: Dattatreya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on February 15, 1951, under order made on February 13, 1951, by District Magistrate, Surat, in exercise of powers under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

Copy of detention order served on petitioner at time of arrest; grounds of detention served same date as required by section 7; specifically mentioned in public interest not to disclose further facts.

Petitioner moved Bombay High Court under Article 226 complaining detention illegal; urged grounds false, vague, fantastic, bad faith; two affidavits filed by State; application dismissed on April 17, 1951.
Case placed before Advisory Board; reported on April 5, 1951, sufficient cause for detention.
Government decided on April 13, 1951, to confirm detention order.

Confidential letter No. B.D. II/1042-D 11 dated April 28, 1951, from Home Department to District Magistrate, Surat, confirming detention order under section 9; instructed to inform detenu and report compliance; signed by G.K. Kharkar for Secretary.

Affidavit of Venilal Tribhovandas Dehejia, Secretary to Government of Bombay, Home Department, confirming facts; Kharkar was Assistant Secretary authorized under rule 12 of Rules of Business under Article 166.
Supplementary petition complaining grounds false, vague, lacking particulars; not pressed before Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether State Government failed to comply with section 11(1) of Preventive Detention Act by not specifying period of detention continuance at confirmation.
Whether confirmation order not in proper legal form, not expressed in name of Governor as required by Article 166(1) of Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 11(1) requires confirmation order to specify period of detention continuance; omission vitiates order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act, s.11(1); Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab (Pet. No. 308 of 1951)

petitioner_arguments.text: Confirmation order not valid as confidential communication to District Magistrate; not formal order expressed in name of Governor per Article 166(1).

respondent_arguments.text: Section 11(1) confers two powers: confirm and continue; no need to specify period in confirmation as detention continues automatically; Act temporary, detention ends with Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive Detention Act, s.11(1); A.K. Gopalan case; S. Krishnan v. State of Madras

respondent_arguments.text: Section 11(1) requires only executive decision, not formal order; confidential letter suffices; Article 166 directory, not mandatory; omission does not invalidate.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution of India, Art.166; J.K. Gas Plant v. King-Emperor; Preventive Detention Act, s.11(1), s.13

court_reasoning.text: Section 11(1) grammatically confers two powers; confirmation decision continues detention automatically; no need to specify period; Act temporary limits duration; consistent with precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specification desirable but not required by plain language; indefinite detention averted by Act's life.

court_reasoning.text: Act requires executive decision for confirmation; no prescribed form; Article 166 directory; decision taken proved by record; letter by authorized officer suffices.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Non-compliance with Art.166 removes immunity but does not nullify decision.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'such period as it thinks fit' presuppose decision on period post-Advisory Board but omission not nullity given temporary Act; implies till Act expiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Specification desirable; Government should comply but omission alone does not justify release.

court_reasoning.text: Section 11(1) contemplates formal order; Art.166(1) directory; signed by authorized officer; proves Governor's order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loss of presumption but validity proved affirmatively.

court_reasoning.text: Words 'such period' require specification; failure prejudices detenu, makes detention illegal as onus on State undischarged.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government must fix period within Act's life; no period means unlawful.

holdings.text: No necessity under s.11(1) to specify period in confirmation order; Art.166 directory; detention valid.
Executive decision suffices; form under Art.166 not mandatory for validity.
Specification of period desirable but omission not nullity.
Failure to specify period makes detention illegal.

precedents_cited.relevance: Section 11 permits continuance till Act expiry; not indefinite.

precedents_cited.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: No period in initial detention order under s.3.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chakar Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Government may extend detention before expiry of prior period under s.11(1).

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Krishnan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: S.11(1) valid; limited by Act's duration.

precedents_cited.case_name: J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co. v. King-Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions like Art.166 directory, not mandatory.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition; procedure for executive action; safeguards for preventive detention.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of detention, grounds, Advisory Board, confirmation, revocation; compliance challenged.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to revoke or modify detention order.

outcome.summary: Application under Article 32 for habeas corpus dismissed; detention held valid by majority as no mandatory requirement to specify period under s.11(1) or formal expression under Art.166(1); procedure followed.

key_quotes.text: "In my judgment, on a proper construction of section 11(1), a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is not necessary, however desirable one may consider it to be."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das J. holding on no need for period specification.

key_quotes.text: "The position, therefore, is that while the Preventive Detention Act requires an executive decision... that Act does not itself prescribe any particular form of expression of that executive decision."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das J. on form of confirmation order.

key_quotes.text: "I am unable to hold that this omission alone would make the order a nullity which will justify us in releasing the detenu."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mukherjea J. on omission of period.

key_quotes.text: "After considerable thought I have reached the conclusion that the non-determination by Government of the period of the continuance of the detention operates prejudicially against the detenu's and makes the detention illegal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mahajan J. dissenting view on period specification.
